data.title: The No. 1 athlete from each of Alabama's 67 counties
data.meta_description: Alabama has produced some of America's greatest athletes, from modern heroes like Bo Jackson, Charles Barkley and Julio Jones to Negro Leagues baseball stars Monte Irvin and Dan Bankhead.
data.text:
Design by Kerry Whipple Bean | For AL.com

Best of the best

AP Photo

Stars fell on Alabama

Alabama has produced some of America’s greatest athletes, from modern heroes like Bo Jackson, Charles Barkley and Julio Jones to Negro Leagues baseball stars Monte Irvin and Dan Bankhead.

RELATED: The most famous person from each of Alabmaa’s 67 counties

Iconic Olympic sprinter Jesse Owens was born here. So were championship boxers Joe Louis, Evander Holyfield and Deontay Wilder.

And who could forget Hank Aaron, the slugger who broke Babe Ruth’s home run record?

Let’s take a by-county look at Alabama’s greatest athletes:

Photo from the documentary 'American Man

Autauga County: Kevin Turner, football

Turner, a 6-foot-1, 241-pounder known for his blocking prowess, played fullback at Alabama from 1988-91. He then spent eight seasons in the NFL with the New England Patriots and Philadelphia Eagles, retiring after the 1999 season. He died earlier this year, at age 46, after battling ALS, the neurodegenerative disease best known as Lou Gehrig's Disease. Research later found he had the most advanced stage of CTE.

John David Mercer/AL.com file

Baldwin County: Julio Jones, football

Jones burst into stardom as a receiver and kick returner at Foley, where he won the Mr. Football Award before starring at Alabama and helping the Crimson Tide win the 2009 national title.

RELATED: Alabama’s greatest football players

A first-round pick by the Atlanta Falcons, he is a three-time Pro Bowler who led the NFL in receiving yards in 2015, when he was also named All-Pro.

Hal Yeager/AL.com file

Barbour County: Don Sutton, baseball

Sutton played 23 seasons in the Major Leagues, winning 324 games, throwing 58 shutouts and five no-hitters. He ranks in the top 10 all-time in strikeouts with more than 3,500. He was born in Clio but grew up in Molino, Florda, just north of Pensacola. He was induced into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1998.

Photo from www.brooklynvisualheritage.org

Bibb County: Fresco Thompson, baseball

Born in Centreville in 1902, his family moved to New Yortk City in 1916. He played football and baseball at Columbia before playing Major League Baseball from 1925-34, playing for the Pittsburgh Pirates, New York Giants, Philadelphia Phillies and Brooklyn Robins/Dodgers. He later became an executive with the Dodgers and rose to general manager.

Mark Almond/AL.com

Blount County: Bryan Kirkland, wheelchair athlete

Kirkland became the first disabled athlete to be inducted into the Alabama Sports Hall of Fame, after a winning Paralympic Gold in wheelchair rugby in 2000 and 2008. In 1998, he competed at the World Wheelchair Games where he medaled in three different track and field events; Gold Medal in the 200m (setting a world record), Silver Medal in 100m, and a Bronze in 400m. In 2003 he was named the USQRA Athlete of the Year.

Bullock County: Jimmy Hitchcock, football & baseball

Known as The Phantom of Union Springs, he led Auburn to the 1932 Southern Conference title and was named to the Walter Camp All-America team. He later played Major League Baseball and returned to Auburn as the school’s baseball coach and an assistant football coach.

TownMapsUSA.com

Butler County: Tom Morrow, football

A Georgiana native, Morrow played at Southern Mississippi and later played three seasons with the Oakland Raiders. He intercepted a pass in eight straight professional games while playing for the Raiders.

AP Photo/Al Golub

Calhoun County: Eric Davis, football

The Anniston native starred at Jacksonville State and was selected in the second round of the 1990 NFL Draft. He played 13 seasons in the NFL, setting a record by intercepting a pass in five straight postseason games. He was a two-time Pro Bowler and three-time All-Pro.

World-Telegram staff photo - via Library of Congress online archive

Chambers County: Joe Louis, boxing

Born in LaFayette, Louis reigned as the world heavyweight boxing champion from 1937-49. He retired with a record of 68-3, with 54 knockouts. He was widely considered one of the first African-Americans to achieve worldwide fame and he also broke golf’s color barrier by playing in a PGA event in 1952.

From Alabama Sports Hall of Fame

Cherokee County: Lindy Hood, basketball

Born in Leesburg, Hood was the first All-American basketball player at the University of Alabama and led the Crimson Tide to an undefeated season in 1929-30. He did not play basketball at Collinsville High School and arrived at the Capstone to play football.'

AL.com file

Chilton County: Harold Morrow, football

The Maplesville product played at Auburn and then spent 1996-2005 in the NFL as a fullback for the Minnesota Vikings, Baltimore Ravens and Arizona Cardianls. He logged only 17 carries and caught 14 passes in 10 NFL seasons.

Johnny Ruffin's 1994 baseball card.

Choctaw County: Johnny Ruffin, baseball

The Butler native played six seasons in Major League Baseball, logging time as a pitcher with the Cincinnati Reds, Arizona Diamondbacks and Florida Marlins. He finished with a record of 10-6 with a 4.13 ERA and 163 strikeouts.

http://www.clarkemuseum.com/

Clarke County: Earlie James, football

James starred at running back in the 1970s at Clarke County High in Grove Hill and was headed to Nebraska before suffering a broken leg against Thomasville. He later played at West Alabama.

Eric Schultz/AL.com file

Clay County: Howard Ballard, football

The Ashland native and Alabama A&M legend played offensive tackle in four Super Bowls during an NFL career that lasted from 1987-1998. He was twice selected to the Pro Bowl and played in 170 career NFL games.

Eric Schultz/AL.om file

Cleburne County: Tyrone Prothro, football

An emerging star receiver and kick returner at Alabama, Prothro suffered a career-ending injury during a 31-3 victory over Florida on Oct. 1, 2005. He was the 2006 Espy for Best Play for his acrobatic catch against Southern Miss on Sept. 19, 2005. After his injury, he never played again, and he finished his career with 58 catches for 863 yards and five TDs.

Photo Courtesy of TimesDaily

Coffee County: Ronald McKinnon, football

An Elba native, McKinnon became a four-time All-Gulf South Conference player and a three-time Division II All-American at North Alabama, as the Lions went 48-5-1 and won three straight NCAA Division II national titles with McKinnon.

RELATED: The unknown story of how UNA signed Ronald McKinnon

He won the Harlon Hill Trophy in 1995 and is the only defensive player to ever win the award.

Mark Almond/AL.com

Colbert County: Ozzie Newsome, football

Newsome starred at Colbert County High in Leighton before starring at Alabama, starting 48 straight games en route to three straight SEC titles. At Alabama, he had 102 receptions for 2,070 yards and was a consensus All-American as a senior. He then started 176 of 182 games with the Cleveland Browns, finishing his career as the Browns' all-time leading receiver and the all-time leading receiver for NFL tight ends. He later became an NFL executive.

Conecuh County: Ken Clark, football

The Evergreen native played running back at Nebraska and was twice named to the All-Big 8 Team. In 1988, he ran for 256 yards and three TDs in a victory over Oklahoma State and eventual Heisman Trophy winner Barry Sanders. He ran for more than 3,000 yards in college and later played in 34 NFL games.

AP Photo/Bill Kostroun

Coosa County: Justin Tuck, football

First known for his basketball ability at Coosa Central, he became a standout linebacker and tight end and signed with Notre Dame. He finished his college career with 24.5 sacks and 43 tackles for loss and then sepent 2005-15 in the NFL, helping the New York Giants win two Super Bowls. He finished his NFL career with more than 500 tackles and 22 forced fumbles.

AP Photo/Bill Kostron

Covington County: Robert Horry, basketball

The 6-foot-10 forward from Andalusia starred at Alabama, setting the career record for blocked shots, before winning seven NBA titles with three different teams. He became a 3-point shooting specialist and earned the nickname "Big Shot Rob" for his clutch shooting during his 16-year NBA career.

Julie Bennett/jbennett@al.com

Crenshaw County: Chuck Person, basketball

The Brantley product left Auburn as the school's all-time leading scorer with more than 2,300 points, helping the Tigers make NCAA Tournament appearances in 1984, 1985 and 1986. He played in the NBA from 1986-2000 and averaged double-digit scoring for 10 consecutive seasons.

Mark Almond/AL.com

Cullman County: Josh Rutledge, baseball

After emerging as a baseball star at Cullman High, Rutledge immediately became a standout shortstop at Alabama and led the team in hitting, stolen bases and runs scored as a freshman. He has played in the Major Leagues for the Colorado Rockies and Boston Red Sox, with 20 career homers and 23 career stolen bases.

AL.com file

Dale County: Wilbur Jackson, football

The Ozark native was the first African-American to sign a football scholarship at Alabama. In 1973 he was consensus All-American and All-SEC as a halfback in the wishbone offense, rushing for 752 yards on 95 carries. He ran for 138 yards on just five carries against Virginia Tech in 1973. He became the NFL Rookie of the Year for the San Francisco 49ers and later played on the Washington Redskins’ 1982 Super Bowl-winning team.

AP Photo/Adam Butle

Dallas County: Mia Hamm, soccer

Born in Selma to a military family, she became the most decorated female soccer player in American history. As a college player at North Carolina, she won four national titles while setting ACC records for goals (103), assists (72) and points (278). She later won two Gold Medals in the Olympics as a member of the U.S. Soccer Team and led the U.S. Women to a World Cup title. Hamm scored 158 goals in international competition.

Photo by RacingOne/Getty Images

Dekalb County: Tim Flock, auto racing

Born in Fort Payne, Flock won the series championship in the Grand National Series – the forerunner of today’s Cup series -- in 1952 and 1955, and he won 19 poles in 1955. He was disqualified and banned bdy NASCAR for a rules violation, but it’s widely viewed that his ban was a retaliation for his support of a NASCAR drivers’ union. He won 40 Cup races in 189 starts.

AL.com file

Elmore County: Joe Sewell, baseball

The Titus native played football and baseball at Alabama and later played in Major Leagues from 1920-33. He made his deput in 1920 as a replacement for Ray Chapman, who was killed when struck in the head from a pitch by Carl Mays. He holds the record for lowest career strikeout, with just 114 strikeouts in more than 7,100 at-bats. He compiled a career .312 batting average and was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1977. The baseball stadium at Alabama is named in Sewell’s honor.

AP Photo/Jack Smith

Escambia County: Evander Holyfield, boxing

Born in Atmore but raised in Atlanta, Holyfield was the undisputed cruiserweight and heavyweight boxing champion of the world. He fought Mike Tyson in two memorable fights, including one in which Tyson bit off a piece of Holyfield’s ear. His professional record was 44 wins, 10 losses, with 29 KOs.

Bill Starling/AL.com file

Etowah County: Carnell "Cadillac" Williams

Named Alabama's Mr. Football for the Etowah in 2000, Williams became an All-American running back and the SEC Special Teams Player of the Year for Auburn's undefeated 2004 team and the NFL Offensive Rookie of the Year for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in 2005. No Auburn player has scored more touchdowns than Williams, who had 46, and he also ranks first in rushing attempts and second in all-purpose yards and rushing yards on the Tigers' career lists. The fifth player picked in the 2005 draft, Williams spent six seasons in the NFL, running for 4,038 yards and 21 touchdowns and catching 148 passes for 1,002 yards and four TDs.

Photo byHal Yeager/AL.com

Fayette County: Mike Davis, basketball

The state's top basketball prospect in 1979, Davis signed with Alabama and became a defensive specialist and won the team’s Hustle Award all four seasons while averaging 10.1 points per game in his career. He played professionally in Europe and the CBA before becoming a basketball college head coach at Indiana, UAB and currently at Texas Southern.

University of Mississippi/AP photo

Franklin County: Chucky Mullins, football

An All-State football player at Russellville, Mullins signed with Ole Miss and became a contributor after redshirting. On Oct. 28, 1989 against Vanderbilt, he hit Brad Gaines and was paralyzed. He returned to Oxford, Miss., in January 19912 to pursue his degree, but he died in May 1991 after collapsing from complications resulting from a blood clot.

“Chucky's battle with his physical disability and his undefeatable spirit changed the University of Mississippi,” reads information on Ole Miss’ website about him. “For months after the tragic accident, Chucky endured the grueling challenges of rehabilitation. During the difficult time, Chucky's gritty determination and positive spirit touched the lives of literally hundreds of people. More than a million dollars was raised for the Chucky Mullins Trust Fund. He was visited in the hospital and later at home by such stars as Walter Payton, Janet Jackson and President George Bush. Chucky's accident and his unbroken spirit transcended football. The people of Mississippi, the South and the entire United States rallied around this remarkable young man.”

Geneva County: Early Wynn, baseball

Born in Hartford, a broken leg ended his football career and led him to the baseball diamond as a pitcher. He spent 23 seasons in a Major League career interrupted by World War II. He was a nine-time all-star who led the big leagues in victories in 1954 and 1959 and won the 1959 AL Cy Young Award. He finished with a career record of 300-244 with more than 2,300 strikeouts. Elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1972, he was known for his toughness and his propensity to pitch inside. “I'd knock down my own grandmother if she dug in on me,” he once said.

Greene County: Willie "Pee Wee" Powell, baseball

A native of Eutaw, he pitched in the Negro Leagues from 1925-34, mostly with the Chicago American Giants. He threw a no-hitter in 1927, according to Wikipedia.

Alabama Sports Hall of Fame

Hale County: Riggs Stephenson, football and baseball

Known as “Old Hoss,” the Akron native played football and baseball at Alabama before playing Major League Baseball from 1921-34. He compiled a career batting average of .336, although a shoulder injury from a football game harmed his ability to throw. University President George Denny once called him “the embodiment of cleanliness, manliness, and courage."

Henry County: Monte Irvin, baseball

Born in tiny Haleburg who grew up in Orange, New Jersey, Irvin was as a five-time all-star in the Negro Leagues who became one of the first African-American players in the Major Leagues when he joined the New York Giants in 1949. He teamed with Hank Thompson and Willie Mays to make up the first all-black outfield in MLB history. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1973. Irvin died earlier this year.

AL.com file

Houston County: Artis Gilmore, basketball

A standout at Dothan’s Carver High, the 7-foot-2 giant played collegeiately at Gardner-Webb (N.C.) and Jacksonville (Fla.) and averaged an NCAA record 22.7 rebounds per game. In 1971, he was selected the ABA Rookie of the Year and league MVP and later was a six-time NBA All-Star. In the ABA and NBA, he blocked more than 3,000 shots and averaged more than 12 rebounds per game.

AL.com file

Jackson County: Sanders Russell, harness racing

The Stevenson native and Jackson County High graduate played baseball and tennis at Auburn before becoming a harness racing champion. The U.S. Trotting Association's official records credit him with 1,116 first places, 531 seconds and 503 thirds. He won more than 20 major stakes with world records in 1946 and ‘55. His total winnings were over $2 million.

AL.com file

Jefferson County: Bo Jackson, football and baseball

The Bessemer native starred in football, basetball and track at McAdory High and Auburn, where he won the Heisman Trophy in 1985. He played Major League Baseball from 1986-94 and for the NFL's Los Angeles Raiders. He was MVP of the 1989 MLB All-Star Game and was a NFL Pro Bowler in 1990, but a hip injury ended his career.

AL.com file photo by Jerrell Rowell

Lamar County: Joe Cribbs, football

The Sulligent native starred at Sulligent High and at Auburn before a professional career that included stints with the NFL's Buffalo Bills and USFL's Birmingham Stallions. He ran for more than 5,000 yards and 27 TDs in the NFL and was named to three Pro Bowls.

AP photo

Lauderdale County: Harlon Hill, football

Hill was a standout at Florence State Teachers College (now North Alabama) from 1950-53 and then was the NFL Rookie of the Year for the Chicago Bears in 1954 when he finished with 1,124 yards receiving and 12 TDs. He finished his pro career with 226 receptions were for 4,616 yards for a 20.4 yards per catch average. The Harlon Hill Trophy goes to the best player in NCAA Division II football, and it’s considered the division’s equivalent of the Heisman Trophy.

AP photo

Lawrence County: Jesse Owens, track and field

Born in tiny Oakville as the grandson of slaves, Owens set world records in the 100- and 200-yard dash events as a high school sprinter in Cleveland, Ohio. He became a worldwide track icon at the 1936 Olympics in Berlin, winning gold medals in the 100-meter, 200-meter, long jump and 4x100-meter relay team. Upon his death, President Jimmy Carter issued a statement that read, "Perhaps no athlete better symbolized the human struggle against tyranny, poverty and racial bigotry."

AP Photo/Donna McWilliam

Lee County: Demarcus Ware, football

Born in Auburn, Ware played college football at Troy after Alabama and hometown Auburn overlooked him. He has become one of the NFL’s all-time best pass rushers, earned nine Pro Bowl invitations and four times being named All-Pro. He has more than 130 career sacks and 50 forced fumbles and is still active as a member of the Denver Broncos.

AP Photo/Gail Burton

Limestone County: Philip Rivers, football

A standout at Athens High who was recruited to play other positions by Alabama and Auburn, Rivers has become one of the most prolific NFL quarterbacks of his era. He is a five-time Pro Bowler who has thrown for more than 45,000 yards and more than 300 touchdowns in his career with the San Diego Chargers that started in 2004. He threw for a career-best 4,792 yards in 2015 and has 3,589 passing yards through 13 games this season.

AP Photo/Paul Sancya

Lowndes County: Ben Wallace, basketball

The 6-foot-9 basketball star was born in White Hall and played collegiately at Cuyahoga Community College and Virginia Union. He became a four-time NBA Defensive Player of the Year for the Detroit Pistons, who blocked more than 2,000 shots in his professional career that lasted from 1996-2012. He was also one of the league’s leading rebounders for much of his career.

AL.com file photo from 2000

Macon County: Alice Coachman Davis, track and field

Born in Albany, Ga., she came to Tuskegee to be coached by legendary coach Cleve Abbott. She became the first African-American woman to win a gold medal by high-jumping 5 feet, 6 1/8 inches at the 1948 Olympics in London after the 1940 and 1944 Olympic Games’ were cancelled because of World War II.

Sarah Cole/AL.com

Madison County: Condredge Holloway, football and baseball

A standout baseball, basketball and football player at Lee-Huntsville High, he became the first African-American quarterback in the SEC at Tennesssee, where he was known as "The Artful Dodger." He ended his career with the best career interception-to-attempt ratio in Tennessee history, throwing 12 interceptions in 407 attempts. He was the fourth overall pick in the 1971 MLB Draft by the Montreal Expos, but went to Tennessee instead. He later played in the CFL, capturing the CFL's Most Outstanding Player award in 1982 and won two Grey Cup championships.

Marengo County: David Beverly, football

The Sweet Water High graduate walked on at Auburn and became an All-SEC punter in 1971. He played in the NFL from 1974-80, playing in 102 games for the Houston Oilers and Green Bay Packers.

TownMapsUSA.com

Marion County: Hayden Riley, basketball

Raised in Guin, Riley was a four-sport athlete in high school and later played football, baseball and basketball at Howard College in Birmingham, now known as Samford University. After World War II, he later played basketball at Alabama. He’s best known for coaching basketball at Alabama, first as an assistant from 1958-60 and later as the ehad coach from 1960-68. He also coached baseball at Alabama.

AL.com file

Marshall County: John Hannah, football

Dubbed the "Best Offensive Lineman of All-Time" by Sports Illustrated in 1981, his career began as a national high school wrestling champion and football star at The Baylor School in Chattanooga, Tenn., before playing his senior season at Albertville High. After starring at Alabama, he was the fourth overall pick in the 1973 NFL Draft by the New England Patriots, earned spots on the NFL 75th Anniversary All-Time Team, the NFL All-1970s Team and the NFL All-1980s team, was named All-Pro 10 times, and was elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1991.

AP Photo/Harry Harris

Mobile County: Hank Aaron, baseball

Aaron spent 23 seasons, mostly as an outfielder, with Milwaukee and Atlanta Braves and finished his career as the all-time home run leader with 755 homers. He broke Babe Ruth’s career home run record by hitting his 715th homer in April 1974. ““I never want them to forget Babe Ruth. I just want them to remember Henry Aaron,” he said during his 1982 induction into the Baseball Hall of Fame.

Atlanta Journal-Constitution file photo

Monroe County: John Drew, basketball

Born in tiny Vredenburgh, he remains the career and single-season scoring leader in AHSAA history, averaging 41 points per game during his career at J.F. Shields. In 11 NBA seasons, he averaged 20.7 points and averaged 10.7 rebounds as a rookie in 1974-75. His career ended because of his cocaine addiction and he became the first player banned for substance abuse in 1986.

"He never had an off night," high school teammate Jerome Sanders told AL.com in 2010. "He put them numbers up, but it never did fascinate us because we knew, 'Hey, if he's open at the top of the key, that's money in the bank.' We didn't even worry about trying to box out or anything because we knew it was accurate."

Frank Couch/AL.com

Montgomery County: Bart Starr, football

A 17th-round draft pick in 1956 after playing little during his final two seasons at Alabama, he took over as the Green Bay Packers' starting quarterback in 1959.

RELATED: How brutal hazing at Alabama nearly ended Bart Starr's career

He was named the MVP of the first two Super Bowls, won the league MVP award in 1966, posted a 9-1 postseason record, and was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame in 1977. He threw for 24,718 yards and 152 touchdowns in his career.

AL.com file

Morgan County: Vicki Orr Wiley, basketball

The Hartselle native is considered the greatest women's basketball player in state history. At Auburn, she was a three-time All-American, was named SEC Player of the Year in 1988, led the Tigers to three straight Final Fours and later played on the 1992 U.S. Olympic Team. She also played professionally in Europe.

AL.com file

Perry County: Zeke Smith

The Uniontown native won the Outland Trophy as college football best interior lineman in 1958 at Auburn. He started on Auburn’s 1957 national championship team and then was named All-American in 1958 and 1959. He played briefly in the NFL for the Baltimore Colts and New York Giants.

AP photo

Pickens County: Walter Jones, football

The Aliceville native played at Holmes County (Miss.) Community College before starring at Florida State. A first-round pick in the 1997 NFL Draft by the Seattle Seahawns, the massive offensive tackle was a nine-time Pro Bowler and four-time All-Pro. His No. 71 jersey was retired by the Seahawks. He started all 180 NFL games in which he played.

RELATED: Look inside Walter Jones' mansion

AL.com file

Pike County: Fred Baxter, football

A tight end at Auburn and in the NFL, he was a high school football star who played quarterback and receiver and once hit three triples in a high school baseball game. He played tight end in the NFL from 1993-2002, he caught 100 passes for 1,008 yards and 12 touchdowns.

Randolph County: Horace Gillom, football

A Roanoke native who grew up in Masillion, Ohio, Gillom pioneered modern punting by catching the snap deeper than normal to allow him to punt with more power and give the kick more hangtime. A punter and defensive lineman at Ohio State, he played for the Cleveland Browns from 1947-56 when the Browns won three NFL championships.

Morry Gash/AP

Russell County: Tim Hudson, baseball

From Phenix City, Hudson led Glenwood to an AISA baseball title in 1993 and later played at Chattahoochee Community College and Auburn. At Auburn in 1997, he hit .396 with 18 homers and 95 RBIs and went 15-2 as a pitcher who moonlighted as an outfielder. He then spent 17 seasons in the Major Leagues, going 222-133 with a 3.49 ERA and a more than 2,000 strikeouts.

Shelby County: Howard Hill, archery

Born in Wilsonville in 1899, he played baseball at Auburn but is best known as The World’s Greatest Archer. He won 196 consecutive field archery tournaments from 1926-42, according to the his Alabama Sports Hall of Fame bio, and he performed practically all the archery stunts in Hollywood movies in the 1940s and 1950s.

Julie Bennett/jbennett@al.com

St. Clair County: Charles Barkley, basketball

This is a stretch, but Leeds – Barkley’s hometown – is in Jefferson, Shelby and St. Clair counties. So, we’ll put Sir Charles here. How could we have this list without him?

The Leeds native became the 12th player in NBA history to reach the 20,000 points and 10,000 rebounds and he was named one of the 50 greatest players of all-time. As a star at Abuurn, he led the SEC in rebounding three times and earned the nickname, “The Round Mound of Rebound” for his husky frame. He was the SEC Player of the Year in 1984.

Courtesy of the Kansas City Chiefs

Sumter County: Buck Buchanan, football

A native of Gainesville who played at Parker High in Birmingham before starring at Grambling (La.) State for legendary coach Eddie Robinson, the 6-foot-7, 287-pounder was a six-time All-AFL selection, a two-time Pro Bowl honoree, had his number retired by the Chiefs and won Super Bowl IV. A durable player who played in 166 straight pro games, he is a member of the College and Pro Football Halls of Fame.

AP Photo/David J. Phillip

Talladega County: Gerald Wallace, basketball

The national high school player of the year at Childersburg, he played one season at Alabama before playing in the NBA from 2001-15. A high-flying dunk artist early in his career, he earned a reputation for a reckless style of play that led to a series of injuries but often kept him in the lineup. He averaged at least 13 points per game for nine straight season, including a career high 19.4 points per game in 2007-08.

AP Photo/Mike Thomas

Tallapoosa County: Terrell Owens, football

The Benjamin Russell grad played football and basketball at Tennessee-Chattanooga and was selected in the third round of the 1996 NFL Draft by the San Francisco 49ers. One of the most controversial players in NFL history, he is a six-time Pro Bowl selection and a member of the NFL All-2000s Team. He caught 1,078 passes for 15,935 yards and 156 TDs. His 156 TDs ranks fifth all-time in NFL history.

AP Photo/Frank Franklin II

Tuscaloosa County: Deontay Wilder, boxing

The reigning WBC heavyweight boxing champion of the world, the Bronze Bomber also won a bronze medal at the 2008 Olympics. He currently has a professional record of 37-0, with 36 knockouts, and he has defended his championship three times in Birmingham.

Walker County: Dan Bankhead, baseball

An Empire native, the longtime Negro Leagues star became the first African-American pitcher in Major League Baseball with the Brooklyn Dodgers in 1947. His brothers Sam, Fred, Joe and Garnett also played baseball in the Negro Leagues. He also hit a home run in his first Major League at-bat.

Wikipedia.com

Washington County: Wilmer Mizell, baseball

Born in Vinager Bend, the left-handed pitcher grew up in nearby Leakesville, Mississippi. He played for the St. Louis Cardinals, Pittsburgh Pirates and New York Mets from 1952-53 and 1956-62, compiling a record of 90-88 and pitching 61 complete games. He later served as Republican Congressman from North Carolina from 1969-75 later served in the administrations of Presidents Gerald Ford and Ronald Reagan.

TownmapsUSA.com

Wilcox County: Jimmy Newberry, baseball

A right-handed pitcher and Camden native, he broke into the Negro Leagues for the Birmingham Black Barons in 1944 and played professionally until 1956. He and John Britton became the first African-Americans to play for a Japanese professional baseball team.

TownmapsUSA.com

Winston County: Ben Smith, football

The Haleville native played end at Alabama and then played in the NFL from 1933-37, logging time with the Green Bay Packers, Pittsburgh Pirates, Pittsburgh Americans and Washington Redskins.

Who else?

Alabama has plenty of other notable athletes who have made their mark through the years. Quarterback Ken Stabler, from Baldwin County, is now a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

In Mobile County, there's baseball legend Satchel Paige and NFL quarterback Richard Todd. In Jefferson County, there's baseball Hall of Famer Willie Mays and current NFL quarterback Jameis Winston.

This goes on and on and on ...
